Looks like some issue resolving artifacts, let me recheck repositories content and retrigger the build if everything is fine:

The following artifacts could not be resolved: org.apache.hbase:hbase-common:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-mapreduce:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-metrics-api:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-metrics:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-protocol:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-protocol-shaded:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-client:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-server:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-hadoop-compat:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-hadoop2-compat:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-zookeeper:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-it:jar:tests:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-common:jar:tests:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-server:jar:tests:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-testing-util:jar:2.4.6, org.apache.hbase:hbase-endpoint:jar:2.4.6: Could not find artifact org.apache.hbase:hbase-common:jar:2.4.6 in apache release (https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/releases/) -> [Help 1]
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e switch.
[ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging.
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please read the following articles:
[ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/DependencyResolutionException

Interesting.
The CI checks recompile hbase from the officially released source to get around the Hadoop3 issue, and so did I in my local tests.
It seems that the 2.4.6 release process hasn't been completed, and the artifacts weren't pulished to maven.
We should probably wait until that is resolved. (and notify the HBase project)
@apurtell Do you know the reason ?
@stoty It's resolved now, just triggered the QA run.

I still cannot see 2.4.6 on https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/org/apache/hbase/hbase-client/
(though it may just take some time to catch up)

> I still cannot see 2.4.6 on https://repo.maven.apache.org/maven2/org/apache/hbase/hbase-client/
> (though it may just take some time to catch up)

Yeah it should show up after some time. It's present here in r.a.o though https://repository.apache.org/content/repositories/releases/org/apache/hbase/hbase-client/2.4.6/
@jpisaac I cannot request a review from you for some reason, but PTAL.

It has appeared. Thanks for your intervention.
However, we do not use the public hbase maven artifacts anywhere in the CI pipeline for 5.x, so it shouldn't make a difference for the CI run.
giving up
giving up

I read the following article I clarified my ideas:
https://www.xaprb.com/blog/2006/05/18/why-null-never-compares-false-to-anything-in-sql/

It remenber me a puzzle that I read in this book (http://www.javapuzzlers.com/) where you can have a instance like this:
---
if (a!=a)
    System.out.println('Hello!! I am here");
---
And the mesage will be shown. How? well... initializating a like:
double a = Math.log(-1);

In this case, a is 'NaN'; and java spec saiys that 'NaN' is not equal to anything... neither NaN, so ' NaN  != NaN' is true.

Do we already prevent create table on preexisting table with salt set?

> Do we already prevent create table on preexisting table with salt set?

I wouldn't want to prevent that.
Copying/Loading a Phoenix data table with HBase tools into a cluster, and then running _create table_ to re-create the Phoenix metadata is a supported and standard procedure, (even if I have seen people messing that up.)

I haven't tested it, but as we're not creating a new HBase table, we probably either error out, or just ignore the pre-split points in this case. I'm going to try out what happens in this case.

> > Do we already prevent create table on preexisting table with salt set?
> 
> I wouldn't want to prevent that. Copying/Loading a Phoenix data table with HBase tools into a cluster, and then running _create table_ to re-create the Phoenix metadata is a supported and standard procedure, (even if I have seen people messing that up.)
> 
> I haven't tested it, but as we're not creating a new HBase table, we probably either error out, or just ignore the pre-split points in this case. I'm going to try out what happens in this case.

I know we had a case in pre-production where we got region boundaries that overlapped the salt boundaries via restore or manual create table ontop of existing table.  This led to wrong results due to phoenix's explicit assumption on the salted boundaries.  Maybe a better approach for this worry is to check during create table that the table is split sanely if its salted etc.
